properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Visibilities may be significantly reduced in snow and blowing snow as an Alberta Clipper moves through northeastern Ontario today. Snow and wind gusts up to 70 km/h are expected this afternoon and evening. Falling snow along with strong wind gusts will allow for blowing snow to occur and affect travel. Conditions will improve later this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T04:28:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T12:29:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0888863195.2020
Area: Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake, Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain is expected. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Locations: Port aux Basques and Burgeo regions. Time span: Monday morning through Tuesday morning. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, is forecast to begin early Monday morning. Currently, the highest rainfall amounts are expected to be inland and over higher terrain, although coastal communities may still see significant amounts. The rain will taper off Monday night. Additionally, strong southerly winds will develop on Monday for which wind warnings have been issued. Please refer to those warnings for more details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:26:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:27:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3358089548.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall amounts are expected over the Appalachians early this week. Snow will begin over the Eastern Townships and Beauce Monday morning then over the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula in the afternoon. Total amounts are forecast to reach near 10 centimetres by Tuesday morning, and could even reach 15 or 20 centimetres locally, especially over higher terrain. Quickly accumulating snow and reduced visibilities are expected to create difficult road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T01:55:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T09:56:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2888481746.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds and local blowing snow. As the Alberta Clipper tracks eastward across Ontario. strong wind gusts of 70 to 80 km/h are expected to develop this morning. The gusty winds could produce local blowing snow reducing visibilities at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T22:05:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T10:25:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1646890038.2020
Area: Attawapiskat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wind is expected. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except 110 along parts of the coast. Locations: southern, eastern, and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: midday Monday to Tuesday morning. Remarks: Strong south to southeasterly winds will increase across the island through the day on Monday. A period of strong southwesterly winds will follow late Monday night into Tuesday morning. Anyone who has Halloween decorations outdoors should consider bringing them inside before Monday, as they are at risk of being tossed by the wind. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:28:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:29:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3781903579.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm with higher amounts possible. Locations: central Labrador, Groswater Bay to the north Labrador coast. Time span: Monday through Tuesday afternoon. Remarks: Rain or snow will begin over most areas by early Monday morning then transition to snow later in the day or Monday evening and persist into Tuesday morning. Conditions will improve by Tuesday afternoon. In addition strong northerlies will develop Monday evening causing reduced visibility in blowing snow over exposed areas. At this time, there is considerable uncertainty regarding the track of the system, which could cause snowfall amounts to vary significantly or shift to adjacent regions. Please monitor your local forecast for future updates. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:48:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:49:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0717367287.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity, Upper Lake Melville, Churchill Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Sasktel Planned Service Outage In Iroquois Lake, Echo Bay And Shell Lake
properties.Summary:
Description: On November 2nd, from 12:00 am (midnight) until approximately 6:00 am, SaskTel crews will be performing maintenance on the network infrastructure serving the Iroquois Lake and Echo Bay area. During that timeframe, SaskTel Internet, Wireless, and Landline Phone services will be unavailable. SaskTel Internet and Wireless services in the Village of Shell Lake will also be unavailable, however, Shell Lake customers will have access to Landline Phone service during the outage.
Expires: 2020-11-02T10:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK SaskTel, 2020-11-01T10:10:14-06:00, 48FD7EA9-F39F-4772-F2F6-79D8F05F088E
Area: Iroquois Lake, Echo Bay and Shell Lake
properties.Author: SK SaskTel

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous frontal system will move onto the north coast this afternoon. Winds over Haida Gwaii and the exposed area of north coast - coastal sections will increase to southerly 90 km/h gusting to 110 this afternoon and persist through early Monday morning. The front will move onto the central coast on Monday. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:54:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:55:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2220840040.2020
Area: Haida Gwaii, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wind is expected. Maximum wind gusts: southerly 80 km/h except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: Monday morning through Tuesday morning. Remarks: The strongest gusts are expected in areas prone to enhanced southerly winds. These winds typically occur in the vicinities of the outer Bay of Islands and Bonne Bay. A period of strong southwesterly winds will follow late Monday night into Tuesday morning before easing later on Tuesday. Anyone who has Halloween decorations outdoors should consider bringing them inside before Monday, as they are at risk of being tossed by the wind. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:29:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:30:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4049712546.2020
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Bay St. George
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Flurries at times heavy and local snow squalls are expected to begin this evening and continue through the night. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm in 12 hours are possible especially over the higher terrain south of Collingwood. Strong winds along with the falling snow will reduce visibilities at times and make travel difficult. Snow squalls will taper off Monday morning. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T05:59:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:00:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2212217121.2020
Area: Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, continues. A warm front extending through northern sections of the North Coast will remain stalled over that region until Monday afternoon. North Coast inland sections near Stewart have already received close to 35 mm of rain since midday Saturday and further 90 to 100 mm of rain is possible from this morning through Monday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T04:48:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T12:49:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1461524661.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Les Suetes wind gusts expected tonight and Monday. Maximum wind gusts: up to 110 km/h. Locations: Margaree Harbour to Bay St Lawrence. Time span: Overnight tonight until early Monday afternoon. Remarks: Strong south-southeasterly winds will develop tonight and Monday, with Les Suetes winds gusting up to 90 km/h overnight and up to 110 km/h Monday morning before ending early Monday afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:44:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:45:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3264318828.2020
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A strong weather system is forecast to affect southwestern sections of the Northwest Territories beginning Sunday afternoon and will persist into early next week. Heavy snow is expected with this system with total accumulations possibly exceeding 25 cm by Tuesday morning. The heaviest snow is predicted to fall mostly over higher terrain and over Nahanni National Park, however accumulations are expected in communities east of these regions as well. Blowing snow may also be an issue over the region. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T03:30:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T11:31:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2838597810.2020
Area: Ft. Liard Region including Nahanni Butte - Sambaa K'e
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potentially damaging winds tonight. An Alberta Clipper will bring moderate winds gusting between 60 and 70 km/h today. Winds will then strengthen this evening with gusts up to 90 km/h. Winds will diminish Monday morning. In addition, flurries will develop off of Lake Huron and Georgian Bay tonight. Strong winds along with the falling snow will reduce visibilities at times and make travel difficult. Flurries will end early Monday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T07:12:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T15:13:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1202083241.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A vigorous Pacific frontal system will move through southern Yukon and northern B.C. tonight bringing heavy snowfall and local blowing snow. Snow will begin falling this afternoon and increase in intensity tonight. The snow will taper off for most areas on Monday afternoon. The exact track of the system will impact snowfall totals, however total accumulation of 25 to 35 cm is widely expected with some areas across the Cassiar Mountain region, accumulation up to 40 cm is possible. For Muncho Lake - Stone Mountain Park, the heaviest snow will be between Muncho Lake and Liard River. Strong northerly winds will also accompany this system producing blowing snow and poor visibility. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T04:10:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T12:11:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3179098755.2020
Area: Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park, Watson Lake, Cassiar Mountains, Teslin, Atlin
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A prolonged period of snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain are expected over the region beginning late Sunday afternoon and ending Monday afternoon. The heaviest snow is expected to fall north of High Level towards the Alberta-N.W.T. border, with total accumulations of 10-15 cm possible. A persistent band of freezing rain and ice pellets is expected to set up south of the snow. Ice accretion on surfaces from freezing rain will be highly variable, but could range between 1-5 mm. ### Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T03:21:53-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 130 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: Monday afternoon. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds gusting to 80 km/h will develop overnight tonight. Winds will further increase Monday afternoon with gusts to 130 km/h before diminishing somewhat Monday evening as winds shift to strong southwesterlies. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:26:33-00:00

Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts and local blowing snow expected today. An Alberta Clipper will bring locally strong northwesterly winds with gusts of 70 to 80 km/h today. Strong winds, along with falling snow, will allow for blowing snow to reduce visibilities at times and make travel difficult. Winds will weaken later tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T05:15:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T13:16:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4148652959.2020
Area: Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A vigorous Pacific frontal system will move through southern Yukon and northern B.C. tonight bringing heavy snowfall and local blowing snow. Snow will begin falling this afternoon and increase in intensity tonight. The snow will taper off for most areas on Monday afternoon. The exact track of the system will impact snowfall totals, however total accumulation of 25 to 35 cm is widely expected with some areas across the Cassiar Mountain region, accumulation up to 40 cm is possible. For Muncho Lake - Stone Mountain Park, the heaviest snow will be between Muncho Lake and Liard River. Strong northerly winds will also accompany this system producing blowing snow and poor visibility. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T04:10:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T12:11:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1767150138.2020
Area: Whitehorse, Teslin, Cassiar Mountains, Watson Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions, significant snowfall and very cold wind chill values beginning late this afternoon or early evening. A vigorous Pacific frontal system will arrive late this afternoon or early evening bringing with it significant snowfall and strong winds resulting in blizzard conditions. Blizzard conditions will last through Monday with total snowfall accumulations up to 60 cm. The strong winds will also produce very cold wind chill values near -30. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:49:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T14:50:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3484952522.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp, South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. Near 10 cm of snow is expected tonight as a warm front stalls over northern sections of the Fort Nelson region. The hardest hit areas will be north and east of Fort Nelson, including Highway 77 Liard Highway towards the Northwest Territories border. Snow will end Monday morning as the warm front moves out of the area. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T03:53:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T11:54:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2477171847.2020
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total Rainfall: 40 to 60 mm, with locally higher amounts possible. Time span: beginning this evening through Monday morning. Remarks: Rain at times heavy is expected to begin this evening then taper to a few showers Monday morning. Generally 40 to 60 mm is expected but areas under the heaviest rain bands may see slightly higher accumulations. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-02T06:44:46-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Visibilities may be significantly reduced in snow and blowing snow as an Alberta Clipper moves through northeastern Ontario today. Snow and wind gusts up to 70 km/h are expected to continue this afternoon. Falling snow along with strong wind gusts will allow for blowing snow to occur and affect travel. Conditions will improve later this afternoon or this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
